summary_md: Last round completed a near-exact characterization (up to constants) of MST_log vs Reg_log. Using Kruskal’s integral identity and a sparse threshold graph H(t) we proved MST_log(L∞) ≤ Reg_log(π); norm equivalence lifts this to MST_log^N(π) ≤ C_N·Reg_log(π) for any fixed norm. A residue-class (mod-m, e.g. parity) family gives MST_log=Θ(n) but Reg_log=Θ(n log n), so Reg_log/MST_log=Θ(log n) and no constant-factor reverse bound exists. A trivial per-edge lower bound on MST yields Reg_log(π) ≤ (log(1+n)/log(1+α_N))·MST_log^N(π), so the worst-case gap is Θ(log n) and tight. Sources: Research Notes; Current Proofs.
highlights: Kruskal-integral + sparse H(t) construction yields MST_log(L∞) ≤ ∑_{i=2}^n log(1+min(Δ_i,t_i)) ≤ Reg_log(π).
By norm equivalence, for any fixed norm N there is C_N with MST_log^N(π) ≤ C_N·Reg_log(π) (constants from operator-norm bounds).
Mod-m (parity) permutations give MST_log(π)=Θ(n) but Reg_log(π)=Θ(n log n), so Reg_log/MST_log=Θ(log n) (no reverse domination).
Universal upper bound: Reg_log(π) ≤ (log(1+n)/log(1+α_N))·MST_log^N(π), with explicit c_N for common norms (L∞: log2, L2: log(1+√2), L1: log3).
Thus the worst-case multiplicative gap between the two measures is Θ(log n), and this factor is tight.
next_questions: Compute/optimize the best constants C_N and α_N for common norms (L1,L2,L∞).
Determine leading constants/asymptotics for E[MST_log] and E[Reg_log] under a uniform random permutation.
Search for (or rule out) permutation families with separation > Θ(log n).
